comment: The plan looks like follows: White sequres his weak e2-pawn, then moves the king on the queen side where he is sure from enemy atacks. Next thing rooks are being doubled on the c-line and the pawns on the king side are being pushed in order to restrain the mobility of the black pieces. All of this time black is forced to think about defending the c-pawn and has little or no counterchances. I do not know if this variation is to be improved for black but I pretty sure would not like to try it.
reasoning: The comment accurately identifies the strategic weaknesses in the player's plan, including the vulnerability of the e2-pawn, the limited king mobility, and the restricting pawn moves on the king side.

While it's uncertain if Black can improve their position, opting for this setup seems unwise.
